div.div: Rotational motion involves angular displacement (θ\thetaθ), angular velocity (ω\omegaω), and angular acceleration (α\alphaα).
Newton's laws for rotation include torque (τ\tauτ) and rotational inertia (III) instead of force and mass.

Equations of Motion:
θ=θ0+ω0t+12αt2\theta = \theta_0 + \omega_0 t + \frac{1}{2} \alpha t^2 θ=θ0​+ω0​t+21​αt2
ω=ω0+αt\omega = \omega_0 + \alpha t ω=ω0​+αt
ω2=ω02+2α(θ−θ0)\omega^2 = \omega_0^2 + 2\alpha(\theta - \theta_0) ω2=ω02​+2α(θ−θ0​)
θ=θ0+12(ω0+ω)t\theta = \theta_0 + \frac{1}{2} (\omega_0 + \omega) t θ=θ0​+21​(ω0​+ω)t
Definition: Tendency of a force to rotate an object.

Formula:
τ=r×F⊥=rFsin⁡(ϕ)\tau = r \times F_\perp = r F \sin(\phi) τ=r×F⊥​=rFsin(ϕ)

Momentum of a Rigid Body:
L=IωL = I \omega L=Iω
No external torque: LLL is conserved.
Solve for angular displacement, velocity, or acceleration using rotational motion equations.
Identify lever arms and forces to calculate net torque and angular acceleration.
Apply L=IωL = I \omegaL=Iω to systems with no external torque, such as a figure skater.
Handle torque as a cross product: τ=r×F\tau = \mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{F}τ=r×F.
Define clockwise or counterclockwise as positive and stay consistent.
For off-center rotations: I=ICM+Md2I = I_{\text{CM}} + M d^2I=ICM​+Md2.
Consistent axis and positive sense (counterclockwise often positive).
Analyze rolling and combined motion problems.
